text:

This transcript was lightly cleaned and formatted. Short, slogan-like lines were treated as headings where appropriate.
What is up, YouTube? Just stopped by the warehouse because we got a new flavor. Couple new flavors coming out of stuff. Watermelon grape pump. Absolutely fire. We do not have enough pump flavors and I've been pushing for these. So, I'm very excited to finally get this and training upper body today. So, I'm fired up about that. Quick update on my training. Right now I'm in I don't know what phase 572 or some [beep] of this rehab, but we're coming out on the other end and I have a phase of hypertrophy coming up in the next week. So today's a pretty predominantly hypertrophy day. Got some stained in the background. Spotify has been finding my jams from the AI system. But um yeah, my next phase of programming is a lot more hypertrophy based, which I am fired up about. I have like a chest and back day and then an arm and shoulder day and then a quad day and a hamstring day. Two on, one off. Upper, lower, rest, upper, lower. So, I'm fired up about that. I feel like I've been lacking a lot of drive in the gym. And I texted Justin about this and I'm like, "Yo, is my training going to be like this forever?" Because I'm like ready to lose my [beep] cuz I'm going in the gym and doing like isometric hold split lunges and glute bridges and [beep] rotator cuffs for sets of 30 times six sets. And I was just sick of it to be completely honest, you know. And I was listening to this thing talking about like the only way you see progress in life is through discomfort. And I'm so used to the discomfort being Sorry, that was annoying. The discomfort being training hard and intensity and like pushing through hard training and hard dieting and all these things. And the discomfort that I've been experiencing was just doing the boring little easy [beep] that I did not want to do. And it was for me discomfort because I was [beep] bored and didn't want to do it. But it was what I needed for the progress. My body needed to heal my shoulder. But I'm kind of over that [beep] So, I'm ready to train [beep] hard again and get jack and put some muscle back on because I've gotten to be way too much of a skinny [beep] I'm actually not that skinny yet, but it's coming there. I actually busted a tank top today. It's like 110? here in Florida and I still have no air conditioning in my gym. So, with that being said, I'm going to get the [beep] out of here. I'm gonna drink this on the way to the gym and then I'll see you guys there for a little bit of I mean it's kind of full upper body minus there's no specific delt movement but I'm going to be moving up the weight doing what I do trying to get a nice little pump. All right. So, last week's gym quote was sweat the small stuff because we are beautifully obsessed with doing something. People think it's bad to be obsessed, but we love to be obsessed with the gym. So, we sweat small stuff, every little detail. This week, you're not going to be able to read this at all. My marker died. Now, I can't have a cool whiteboard anymore. Horrible writing, so don't judge me. I don't even know if I know how to spell this. Consistent discomfort equals discomfort. Gross. Holy [beep] I am if dyslexic today. Consistent discomfort equals consistent growth. I don't even know if I still said that right. Pretty much what I'm talking about in the car is what I was thinking about. It's like being in a state of consistent discomfort means that you are consistently growing in some capacity and getting better. And even if you think deeper on that, if you are in a state of consistent discomfort, it means you're consistently changing. Because if you do the same thing consistently, what used to be discomfort then becomes comfort because your body gets used to it. Things that used to be hard now becomes easy or feel easier. So less discomfort means less growth. You have to continuously adapt, continue to evolve and find ways to get better and change and fine-tune your goals and what you're doing and everything like that. So like the discomfort I was having before was just like coming in the gym consistently, not wanting to do the things, but knowing it with what I needed to do to progress. And then it got to a point where I was like, "Okay, you're kind of losing the progress that you were getting from this. The shoulders good enough now. Now it's time to get in the gym and actually start training hard again and getting into this discomfort of intensity and training hard and pushing things and learning how to do that again with my body." And I think the most distinct place that you see this in results is dieting. People who cannot lose weight, who can't get lean, if you're not hungry, if you're
not uncomfortable, you're not going to lose weight. It's like switching your perception of that hunger is bad cuz like we're hardwired to think hunger means we need to eat. But to switch it, be like, "Well, my goal is to get lean or my goal is to lose body fat or lose weight." To sit in that discomfort and to actually be like, "I'm hungry. It feels uncomfortable." That will lead to consistent growth or consistent fat loss. Opposite of growth technically, but growth towards your goal. So, this is the the theme of the week. Step into discomfort. And it's absolutely [beep] applicable to everything in life. What I remember mostly for I really experienced this was in 2022 when I first started working with Hani. I was going through a lot of changes in my life and I still sucked at public speaking and it's something I wanted to get good at. So I just threw myself into consistent discomfort. I put myself into like talks, Q&As;'s. I'd go to events and be like I'll talk in front of a crowd. I agreed to seminars. I did all these things that I did not want to do. And I was so uncomfortable doing all those things. I got anxious before every single time. I was worried. But it made me better and better at it. made me grow in the terms of my skill as a public speaker, but also that confidence led into everywhere else in my life. So being able to seek out discomfort, I think, is so important because if you don't seek it and get the growth that you want, life is going to throw you into discomfort regardless. It's just not going to be by choice, you're going to become a little victim, little [beep] and be complaining about it and not be where you want to be. So, you might as well go find it and build the life you actually want. So, that's my rant for this beautiful Sunday morning. Let's try and get Jack. So then the other side of my uncontrollable things was causing a lot more stress in me and it was stupid little things. It was like not waking up when I told myself I was going to wake up but wasn't doing cardio when I was going to do cardio. I couldn't train hard because of my injury and then I I wasn't dieting anymore. I didn't have this Olympic goal so I wasn't really eating on track. If I went to the pantry and there was a cookie I wanted there and I just eaten an hour ago. I'm like [beep] it. I'm going to eat the cookie. And I did that for a while and it just like made me feel worse about myself. It was so strange to have more freedom. Made me feel more like [beep] trapped and anxious. And I think it's a very common theme amongst a lot of people right now. I think we're at an unfair advantage if I want to empathize with myself in the world of how powerful like our evolutionary brains are to seek out comfort and entertainment and food and abundance. And we have so much [beep] coming at us right now. Like it's so easy just to go on your phone. You're bored for 2 seconds. Pull your phone up. No one experiences boredom anymore. You're a little bit hungry or at least you think you're hungry but you're probably just bored. go in the pantry, grab a [beep] bag of chips, and no one experiences hunger anymore. And that's why I thought like part of the reason why I love bodybuilding so much because it forced you into these things of like starvation for three months essentially. Not starvation, that's very dramatic, but you're extremely hungry for 3 months. You're absolutely focused in a gym pushing yourself past limits that you want to do. You're sore all the time. You're hurting. You're aching. And you still have to go in and do a level of work regardless of how you feel. I think pushing through that discomfort led to so much more confidence and
fulfillment and happiness within myself and ease of anxiety cuz I'm definitely an anxious person who overthinks a lot. And the more I wasn't in control of those things, the more the anxiety started to creep into my life and I wasn't sleeping. I was getting up through the night overthinking and all this stuff. And just being able to take control of the little things like what I put in my mouth, how I'm training in the gym, when I'm waking up, little things with my health and all that stuff makes everything feel so much better. And I think if you don't put yourself into positions of discomfort, you're not going to grow to be able to handle that. And throughout my career, you know, I would put in a lot of positions where I should have like stopped or I should have taken a break or injuries or health issues or personal things going on where it would have made complete sense and everyone would have validated me if I had backed out. But because the goal was so important to me, I pushed through. And what that led wasn't just six Olympias. to finish my career as someone who can handle hard [beep] where you feel less anxious if you believe you're somebody who can handle hard things when it comes your way. And the only way you can become that someone is by going through hard things. So if you live an extremely easy life, you're doing the same habits every day, eating shitty, kind of training, not really hard, going to work at the same time, doing the same [beep] not pushing yourself to get a promotion or anything, you're just going to feel like blah. And then if [beep] life punches you in the face with some crazy [beep] you will not be prepared for it. So, I think inevitably life will present you with some extreme discomfort at one point or another. And if you haven't consciously chosen to put yourself into discomfort prior to that, you will be a lot less mentally prepared for it. There's nothing you can truly prepare for anything in life, but you can make yourself more of a resilient, level-headed, calm person in the face of adversity. And I think that's so powerful. And I don't think people realize the day-to-day ease of anxiety that leads to. You know, I meet so many people who are so stressed and anxious and don't know what to do. And it's like, just go do some hard [beep] Push yourself through some levels of discomfort. Like for me with public speaking, it's been training hard. It's been dieting. It's been fasting for 3 days or whatever it might be. Whatever things I feel like I don't want to do. I'm not a morning person. So, I've been waking up really early every day and I just [beep] hate it in the morning. But like an hour later when I'm awake, I'm like, I'm glad I did that. Tiny things doesn't have to be hard. And you work your way up to big things. like a big goal like the Olympia allows for big challenges to come in my way and a big opportunity for growth. So, I think that's just so important and it's had me actively thinking about like random hardship I could do and that's why I did that 80 hour fast cuz I was like I feel like I'm every time I'm hungry I'm eating. Can I not do that for 3 days and I did it and I felt good after. Just little challenges like that, you know? Maybe one of these days I'm going to go [beep] drop myself in the woods out of a helicopter in Alaska and go hunt some grizzly bears or something. That would be the dream. But like I said, work your way up to some crazy challenges like that. But I don't know. Maybe this is my brain going crazy cuz I'm retired and I'm seeking for something. But I don't really give a [beep] It It feels exciting. Something I want to do. I'm enjoying training hard right now and that's enough for the moment. But I just like to seek some things that lead to discomfort. You know, even the public speaking thing I haven't done in a long time and now I get anxious when I think of doing it again. So I'm like, "All right, [beep] I should probably put myself into that position again because it's something that I'm resisting that I feel fearful of doing." And I really think so much confidence comes from that. And again, this is why I [beep] love the gym so much. And I want to promote [beep] everyone getting in the gym. If I had a piece of advice for any young person of what to do with their life, I'd be like, "Go start working out. Apply the discipline to the gym. Every time you don't want to go, go. When you're tired, go. When you're sore, work harder. Like, keep pushing through those times. Be consistent." And the confidence you build from consistency and doing things you want to do will just apply to everything else in your life. And I think it's so crucial. I'm a huge believer in that. But with all that being said, this
workout is done. I'm going to go get some food. Courtney's making waffles today, so I'm going to go bucking in on that. And that's it. Thank you guys for watching.

I got a DM the other day from this kid and he was asking me, not really asking me, but declaring that he felt lost. He had no direction in life. He's 20 years old. He sees me. I seem to have a clear path of where I'm headed and he doesn't know what to do. And it really got me thinking about a lot of things cuz let me be clear, when I was 20 years old, I had no idea what the [ __ ] I was doing either. But it really got me thinking about a lot of avenues of I've heard that a lot. You know, I've had a lot of conversations with people at events or DMs or whatever it may be of people saying things like this, and it's not a rare occurrence. And I feel like every generation has had their fair share of challenges. In the past, I feel like it was a little bit more physical obvious ones like war, poverty, disease, crazy [ __ ] which I know still exists in the dark world currently. But by and large, I feel like America as a whole on average, the younger generation, their problem isn't finding comfort in hard times, but in avoiding too much comfort and too much pleasure. And I feel like the odds are heavily stacked against the younger generation because I mean, first of all, there's billions and billions and billions of dollars of research going into how to make a phone, social media, anything highly, highly addictive. And we're given that giving kids those at like 8 years old. They have them in school, bring them around everywhere in their pocket. Social media is creating these like crazy role models of like do drugs, party, look cool, chase after girls, do all this [ __ ] And it's like absolutely absurd in my opinion. And I think the ability to abstain from doing the easy, pleasurable thing that's right in front of you and picture a life that you can dream of, asking yourself if a better version of yourself exists. what that version of yourself is. Picturing the plan to get there and actually starting and executing on that plan, I think is such a rare thing right now and so hard for people to stop and even think about given how much constant distraction there is in their life. And that's what made me want to ask this kid. I was like, do you believe a better version of yourself exists? And I'll get into that. But I really, this really got me thinking a lot about role models. Like the idea of a role model and thinking about how when I was young, I had everything so wrong. And I didn't really have a role model in my life helping me. Don't get me wrong, my dad was incredible, but he wasn't really like in my face on my case in my job knowing what I was doing. He was from a different generation. He wasn't close to my age or hadn't recently gone through anything I was going through. And I, full transparency, was just a dumb kid. I thought it was cool to party, to not try in school, to do drugs, to chase after girls, to do all these things. My friends literally thought it was cool to like, and it's funny cuz my brain is still kind of wired to be like, "Yeah, it's fun." You know, of course it is. And people probably listen probably feel the same way, but to like think of going out and drinking and chasing after girls with no like connection or value for who the person is. To not value your education when you're sitting there doing it. To be wasting my time with an education of which I didn't even know where it was leading me cuz I didn't think about what I wanted my future to be. I was just following the path that was put in front of me. To have all these things in front of me that I didn't have someone looking at me and being like, "Do you want to be like a better man? Do you want to be a man period?" Because what I was doing was what boys do, you know, like playing video games and chasing after girls, thinking it's cool to do all these things rather than building meaningful relationships, working on my making myself a better, well-rounded, more educated man to be prepared for taking care of a family and being the man that a woman that I respect would want to even be with. You know, I didn't have anyone kind of in my face being like, "What the [ __ ] do you want to do with your life? Who do you want to be with your life?" asking me if I wanted to be exceptional. 
Page 2
You know, if you ask the average kid, do you want to be exceptional? Do you want to do something great with your life? The answer is usually yes. But their actions very rarely align with it. And I feel like I didn't have anyone. And you don't need someone. The responsibility lies within yourself ultimately always. But I do believe that like a role model could be a huge asset for pushing yourself to ask these hard questions and being like if you want to be exceptional, what you're doing right now is average or even below average. And if you want to continue to be average or below average your whole life, then continue doing this. But you need to make a serious change and start doing hard [ __ ] and letting go of the easy [ __ ] the comfortable, pleasurable [ __ ] Abstain from that to make a better version of yourself. I didn't have someone really asking me that. And it's kind of a it's kind of scary now that like social media because we don't have role models in a real life. So many people I believe and now social media is such a vast array of like who do we look up to? The one with the most followers. You're young. You get on social media. If at that time the realm you fall into it is people who are promoting gambling, sex, drugs. And I'm it sounds like trit to even say those words, but people are literally like smoking weed, promoting gambling and talking about how to get girls, how to sleep with girls casually on social media. And I really think as a whole, all those things hurt men more than they benefit them. It doesn't make you cool. It just kind of takes away from values, genuine real values in life. So essentially trying not to ramble too much. This kid asked me that question in the many times I've been asked. It really got me just thinking about wanting to share that when I was young I had no idea what the [ __ ] I was doing and I didn't have a role model and falling into the wrong role model can get yourself into a bad position. But someone being able to ask you what do you want with your life? Do you believe a better version of yourself exists? And take responsibility to take that in action. And the reason that question to ask yourself is do you believe a better version of yourself exists? Is because if you say yes, you are admitting that you have faith. You have faith that a better version of yourself exists. And the only way to move forward in life is by starting and just taking action. There's no book or 12step program or perfect way that it's going to organize things. And this sounds super trait to say. I know everyone knows that, but people still don't do it. Awareness doesn't mean anything. Action is all that matters. But what do you need for action? Sometimes people like, "What do I need for action?" Well, you need faith. And if you believe a better version of yourself exists, then you already have faith. So, as a young man, speaking to most young men, you need to have faith a better version of yourself exists. You need to take responsibility for your own life into your own hands. Most likely, you're not going to have a role model following you, telling you what to do, asking you these hard questions, and pushing in the right direction. You need to be the one to do that. So, where the [ __ ] do you start? easiest thing to do. Look in your life. See the things that are easy that everybody is doing. What's what in your life is like calls towards you that you can just feel as a vice when you're checking your phone all the time, playing video games, eating shitty food, doing all things. What calls to you that makes you want to do that everyone else is also called to and avoid those things. And just by avoiding those things, you are already going to be ahead of everyone else who's stuck into those things. And then being able to sit down and clearly define the values that are important to you. You can start with like an ideal person that you want to be defining those values. Actually think about that strictly. Like if you say you're going to do something, do it. Be a man of your word. You're not going to succumb to the easy pleasures. You're going to value delayed gratification over easy gratification. You're 
Page 3
going to be respect every single person that you meet. You're not going to lie. You're not going to [ __ ] You're going to work hard. If you're going to do something, you're going to do it with intention rather than halfassing it and just being like, "Oh, at least showing up's half the job." like you need to declare how you want to show up into the world and then stick to those things and just start taking action. And the first bit of action sometimes is just removing the pleasures, starting to do some hardship. And that's also why I really love the gym because the gym requires discipline. Choosing what you put in your mouth versus what you don't put in your mouth requires discipline. Going to the gym when you're tired and working hard requires discipline. And when you show your mind what your body can do by doing hard things and the progress that comes from that, it gives you a bit of momentum where you can start to see and think about things more clearly and start applying that same discipline to other areas of your life. None of it might make sense in the beginning, but I truly believe if you're at least trying to define your values, if you get them wrong, they'll evolve. If you create a path for yourself and you go the wrong way, you will still learn and then you can create a new path from what you've learned there. But if you're just sitting down absorbing comfort constantly and not taking action, you're going to go absolutely nowhere. So realize that you already have faith in yourself. Take responsibility for your own life cuz no one's going to take it for you. Define who you want to become, the values that are going to get you there. And just start by doing something. That's all I got to say. And then the rest will come. I promise you, if you guys actually put the right effort into it and you're not spending your time absorbing [ __ ] the rest will come. All right, so I don't know how long I just ranted in the car. So, let me jump into this workout. I said I wasn't going to rant and here I go. So, shoulders and arms today. I got a giant set to start with a bunch of Oh, wow. This is going to be a lot. Damn. Shoulder giant set, tricep giant set, bicep giant set. Wish me luck. Come on. Come on. Come on. Yeah. Okay. All right. I have no idea if you can hear me because the fans are loud. I don't give a [ __ ] It's hot as hell. That was the first giant set for shoulders. All those exercises were back to back to back. No rest. Just as soon as you can get into it, you go. I took like a little bit of rest between the last two um prone lateral raises just because they were the same movement. I gave myself like 5 10 seconds and then blasted into it. Moving on to triceps now. This split currently I have a chest and tricep day, a back and bicep day, and a shoulders and arms day. So, I'm getting a good amount of volume in my arms. Trying to not have these skinny arms. I feel like genetically the first muscle I lose is my arms, which sucks being retired cuz like all you really need are calves and arms, but it is what it is. At least I have some calves sometimes. So, moving on to tricep. Same thing. Fore superset. Got my favorite tricep exercise in here. Well, close to the decline dumbbell skull crusher. The decline cable easy bar skull crusher. Mouthful. Probably one of my favorite tricep exercise of all time. Dumbbell is a close close call. Very similar movement. So, going to jump into this starting with the dip machine

name: 2025-11-01-(Shoulders arms).pdf
text:
Direction, Role Models, and a High?Volume Shoulders & Arms Day ? Transcript 
Chris Bumstead (CBum) ? Cleaned transcript provided by user 
I got a DM the other day from this kid and he was asking me, not really asking me, but declaring that he felt lost. He had no direction in life. He's 20 years old. He sees me. I seem to have a clear path of where I'm headed and he doesn't know what to do. And it really got me thinking about a lot of things cuz let me be clear, when I was 20 years old, I had no idea what the ? I was doing either. But it really got me thinking about a lot of avenues of I've heard that a lot. You know, I've had a lot of conversations with people at events or DMs or whatever it may be of people saying things like this, and it's not a rare occurrence. And I feel like every generation has had their fair share of challenges. In the past, I feel like it was a little bit more physical obvious ones like war, poverty, disease, crazy ? which I know still exists in the dark world currently. But by and large, I feel like America as a whole on average, the younger generation, their problem isn't finding comfort in hard times, but in avoiding too much comfort and too much pleasure. And I feel like the odds are heavily stacked against the younger generation because I mean, first of all, there's billions and billions and billions of dollars of research going into how to make a phone, social media, anything highly, highly addictive. And we're given that giving kids those at like 8 years old. They have them in school, bring them around everywhere in their pocket. Social media is creating these like crazy role models of like do drugs, party, look cool, chase after girls, do all this ? And it's like absolutely absurd in my opinion. And I think the ability to abstain from doing the easy, pleasurable thing that's right in front of you and picture a life that you can dream of, asking yourself if a better version of yourself exists. what that version of yourself is. Picturing the plan to get there and actually starting and executing on that plan, I think is such a rare thing right now and so hard for people to stop and even think about given how much constant distraction there is in their life. And that's what made me want to ask this kid. I was like, do you believe a better version of yourself exists? And I'll get into that. But I really, this really got me thinking a lot about role models. Like the idea of a role model and thinking about how when I was young, I had everything so wrong. And I didn't really have a role model in my life helping me. Don't get me wrong, my dad was incredible, but he wasn't really like in my face on my case in my job knowing what I was doing. He was from a different generation. He wasn't close to my age or hadn't recently gone through anything I was going through. And I, full transparency, was just a dumb kid. I thought it was cool to party, to not try in school, to do drugs, to chase after girls, to do all these things. My friends literally thought it was cool to like, and it's funny cuz my brain is still kind of wired to be like, "Yeah, it's fun." You know, of course it is. And people probably listen probably feel the same way, but to like think of going out and drinking and chasing after girls with no like connection or value for who the person is. To not value your education when you're sitting there doing it. To be wasting my time with an education of which I didn't even know where it was leading me cuz I didn't think about what I wanted my future to be. I was just following the path that was put in front of me. To have all these things in front of me that I didn't have someone looking at me and being like, "Do you want to be like a better man? Do you want to be a man period?" Because what I was doing was what boys do, you know, like playing video games and chasing after girls, thinking it's cool to do all these things rather than building meaningful relationships, working on my making myself a better, well-rounded, more educated man to be prepared for taking care of a family and being the man that a woman that I
respect would want to even be with. You know, I didn't have anyone kind of in my face being like, "What the ? do you want to do with your life? Who do you want to be with your life?" asking me if I wanted to be exceptional. You know, if you ask the average kid, do you want to be exceptional? Do you want to do something great with your life? The answer is usually yes. But their actions very rarely align with it. And I feel like I didn't have anyone. And you don't need someone. The responsibility lies within yourself ultimately always. But I do believe that like a role model could be a huge asset for pushing yourself to ask these hard questions and being like if you want to be exceptional, what you're doing right now is average or even below average. And if you want to continue to be average or below average your whole life, then continue doing this. But you need to make a serious change and start doing hard ? and letting go of the easy ? the comfortable, pleasurable ? Abstain from that to make a better version of yourself. I didn't have someone really asking me that. And it's kind of a it's kind of scary now that like social media because we don't have role models in a real life. So many people I believe and now social media is such a vast array of like who do we look up to? The one with the most followers. You're young. You get on social media. If at that time the realm you fall into it is people who are promoting gambling, sex, drugs. And I'm it sounds like trit to even say those words, but people are literally like smoking weed, promoting gambling and talking about how to get girls, how to sleep with girls casually on social media. And I really think as a whole, all those things hurt men more than they benefit them. It doesn't make you cool. It just kind of takes away from values, genuine real values in life. So essentially trying not to ramble too much. This kid asked me that question in the many times I've been asked. It really got me just thinking about wanting to share that when I was young I had no idea what the ? I was doing and I didn't have a role model and falling into the wrong role model can get yourself into a bad position. But someone being able to ask you what do you want with your life? Do you believe a better version of yourself exists? And take responsibility to take that in action. And the reason that question to ask yourself is do you believe a better version of yourself exists? Is because if you say yes, you are admitting that you have faith. You have faith that a better version of yourself exists. And the only way to move forward in life is by starting and just taking action. There's no book or 12step program or perfect way that it's going to organize things. And this sounds super trait to say. I know everyone knows that, but people still don't do it. Awareness doesn't mean anything. Action is all that matters. But what do you need for action? Sometimes people like, "What do I need for action?" Well, you need faith. And if you believe a better version of yourself exists, then you already have faith. So, as a young man, speaking to most young men, you need to have faith a better version of yourself exists. You need to take responsibility for your own life into your own hands. Most likely, you're not going to have a role model following you, telling you what to do, asking you these hard questions, and pushing in the right direction. You need to be the one to do that. So, where the ? do you start? easiest thing to do. Look in your life. See the things that are easy that everybody is doing. What's what in your life is like calls towards you that you can just feel as a vice when you're checking your phone all the time, playing video games, eating shitty food, doing all things. What calls to you that makes you want to do that everyone else is also called to and avoid those things. And just by avoiding those things, you are already going to be ahead of everyone else who's stuck into those things. And then being able to sit down and clearly define the values that are important to you. You can start with like an ideal person that you want to be defining those values. Actually think about that strictly. Like if you say you're going to do something, do it. Be a man of your word. You're not going to succumb to the easy pleasures. You're going to value delayed gratification over easy gratification. You're going to be respect every single person that you meet. You're not
going to lie. You're not going to ? You're going to work hard. If you're going to do something, you're going to do it with intention rather than halfassing it and just being like, "Oh, at least showing up's half the job." like you need to declare how you want to show up into the world and then stick to those things and just start taking action. And the first bit of action sometimes is just removing the pleasures, starting to do some hardship. And that's also why I really love the gym because the gym requires discipline. Choosing what you put in your mouth versus what you don't put in your mouth requires discipline. Going to the gym when you're tired and working hard requires discipline. And when you show your mind what your body can do by doing hard things and the progress that comes from that, it gives you a bit of momentum where you can start to see and think about things more clearly and start applying that same discipline to other areas of your life. None of it might make sense in the beginning, but I truly believe if you're at least trying to define your values, if you get them wrong, they'll evolve. If you create a path for yourself and you go the wrong way, you will still learn and then you can create a new path from what you've learned there. But if you're just sitting down absorbing comfort constantly and not taking action, you're going to go absolutely nowhere. So realize that you already have faith in yourself. Take responsibility for your own life cuz no one's going to take it for you. Define who you want to become, the values that are going to get you there. And just start by doing something. That's all I got to say. And then the rest will come. I promise you, if you guys actually put the right effort into it and you're not spending your time absorbing ? the rest will come. With all that being said, my AC is starting to dial me in this car and I'm getting the ? hot as ? out and I'm sitting outside my gym ranting before going to workout. So, it's shoulders and arms. It's beautiful Saturday. I might have some French toast after this workout. So, if you bear with me through this rant, let's go out. All right, so I don't know how long I just ranted in the car. So, let me jump into this workout. I'm still doing really high volume giant sets. built a bunch of strengths doing a ? ton of volume. This is why programming is so important. I really think like the biggest cheat code of training is having proper periodization to not plateau where you can hit different stimuluses so that the body can the muscle can keep getting different stimuluses, continue to grow, not hit plateaus. I said I wasn't going to rant and here I go. So, shoulders and arms today. I got a giant set to start with a bunch of Oh, wow. This is going to be a lot. Damn. Shoulder giant set, tricep giant set, bicep giant set. Wish me luck. Come on. Come on. Come on. Yeah. Okay. All right. I have no idea if you can hear me because the fans are loud. I don't give a ? It's hot as hell. That was the first giant set for shoulders. All those exercises were back to back to back. No rest. Just as soon as you can get into it, you go. I took like a little bit of rest between the last two um prone lateral raises just because they were the same movement. I gave myself like 5 10 seconds and then blasted into it. Moving on to triceps now. This split currently I have a chest and tricep day, a back and bicep day, and a shoulders and arms day. So, I'm getting a good amount of volume in my arms. Trying to not have these skinny arms. I feel like genetically the first muscle I lose is my arms, which sucks being retired cuz like all you really need are calves and arms, but it is what it is. At least I have some calves sometimes. So, moving on to tricep. Same thing. Fore superset. Got my favorite tricep exercise in here. Well, close to the decline dumbbell skull crusher. The decline cable easy bar skull crusher. Mouthful. Probably one of my favorite tricep exercise of all time. Dumbbell is a close close call. Very similar movement. So, going to jump into this starting with the dip machine right behind me and I'll take you guys through it. Okay. Yeah. All [Music] right. So, wrapped up the tricep portion. Just by the way, I'm doing three rounds of all of these giant sets. So, 4 * 3 is 12 * 3 is 36. I'm not good at math, but 36 working sets in this workout. And obviously given that they're supersets, they're not at full intensity of which I were to take 60 to 90 seconds in between. So the
capacity is less of course, but still it's a ? ton of volume into the arms right now. And this isn't something to do all the time. There's an intention that this is part of the program for like two weeks. This is blasting in high carbs in my diet the next couple weeks and then back to regular programming. So, with that being said, going to jump into biceps. I don't have a proper preacher curl flat bench, so I'm going to try and not hit my arms here. Lock it in and get the rest of my arms pumped. Oh yeah. [Music] Hey, Thank you. still a skinny ? but that's okay. Just wrapped up this quite high volume workout with a success. This was like a This is a pure Saturday workout. If you love volume, if you love lifting weights, and you want to get in 36 sets of arms, this is a beautiful way to do it on a Saturday, cuz there's no other time where you have enough time to do this kind of ? And if you're lucky enough that your gym is actually slow enough to do that many giant sets, then God bless. That's probably the biggest restraint when it comes to public gyms. But that's why when we were doing a lot of the programs in standard, we had to a few of the programs have some pretty extensive supersets in them, but we minimized them as much as possible, understanding that most people aren't in a rather empty gym. So, with all that being said, I've been here for way too long. Bradley's nap is about to wrap up and it's Saturday, so it's family time. So, going to head home, get some food in me, fuel up on carbs because I need those to shuttle into my biceps so I'm not a skinny ? anymore. That's it. What are you making, dude? Making you some sourdough French toast with turkey bacon. There you go, my love. Hit it. All right, so post-workout French toast. Courtney's famous French toast. We haven't started a tradition yet because Bradley's not old enough, but hopefully one day our kids are old enough where they can just eat whatever dad wants on a Sunday morning and this can be what we do. So, couple pieces of sourdough, French toast, cuz sourdough is a goat, turkey, bacon, and then whatever that stuff is, coconut whipped stuff. So, probably not a lot of protein in here, but it's all right cuz I had with a shake for breakfast, so we're balancing it out. And it tastes delicious. So, going straight to the arms today. Make that workout worth it. Damn. Byebye.

name: 2025-10-28-(Bulking).pdf
text:
Bulking ? Video Transcript 
Source: User-provided transcript 
Prepared on 2025-10-26 
Notes 
This document is a cleaned, formatted transcript based on the text you provided. Section headers were inferred heuristically from short title-like lines (e.g., questions such as ?How Do I Know When to Bulk??).
Intro 
What is up, YouTube? Today, I'm going to be going over the top questions people ask me on how to bulk. Any questions I get towards bulking, I've kind of compiled in like a top 10, and I'm going to be going going over all of them today so you have them in a concise area pretty much based off my experience rather than just purely science-based stuff. It's everything I've done and learn from my mistakes throughout the years, so you guys can learn from what I've done right and done wrong and hopefully learn faster than I did. First 
How Do I Know When to Bulk? 
question is always, how do I know when to bulk? And I find this such a funny question people ask me cuz I have no [beep] clue when people should bulk. It's very like situation dependent, person dependent, goal dependent. But as a whole, I would say obviously if your goals put on muscle, you should bulk. And if you're not fat, you can bulk. And fat is obviously very different to the average person. But if you're unhappy with the level of body fat you're at, that's super important. I don't think you should bulk yet. Come down to a body fat that you're happier with, maybe a little bit below even, and then work your way back up. But as a general rule of thumb, I like to be like around 12% body fat for men, maybe 18 to 20 for women, but having visible abs for men specifically, it's easier to gauge. So if my abs are still poking through a little bit, then I'm good to go and I know I haven't bulked too far or I'm good to bulk. Next question, tail off 
How Do I Know When to Stop Bulking? 
that last one, is how do I know when to stop bulking? And similar to when you know if you should bulk, if you start to lose your abs or if you get too much of a high body fat percentage, I always struggled to say that. I got it that time. Then you know it's time to slow down. There's a few other things like when your appetite is absolutely like in this [beep] like you can't eat at all. It'll be tough to eat when you're bulking really hard. One is completely gone. Sometimes you need to just take a step back. If your lifts in the gym are plateauing, if your weight is stagnating, all these different things, it's kind of time to give your body a little bit of a break, whether it be for a week or a full cut. It kind of depends on your goals and situation, of course. But again, big thing is if you have some abs, you're still happy with how you look, you're not too fat yet, then you can keep pushing that weight. All right. 
Macronutrient Essentials 
So, how to start? How to start your base calories, macros, meal plan, whatever it may be. The simplest thing and that everybody needs to do in the suggestions quote is he always says what isn't measured isn't managed. So, the more you measure, the more you can manage, the more you can adapt and you know what changes you're making are causing the changes in your body. So, the most important step of starting anyone's fitness journey really is tracking everything you eat consistently and calculate the calories and macros on that. Maybe do it for a week, take the average and see what it is and weigh yourself during all those days as well. So, if I'm 250 lbs, I'm eating 4,000 calories every single day. Then my base to maintain 250 lb is 4,000 calories. So, if I want to lose weight, I'll go under that. If I want to gain weight, I'll go over that. Typically, you'll increase by like 5 to 10, probably like 5%, I would say. I usually go on more so like 300 to 500 calorie increase when I start a bulk. So, if I'm resting at 4,000, I'll go up to 4500. And then from there, you count your macros through that. Obviously, most important if
PROTEIN 
you're trying to bulk put on muscle is protein. And you don't need quite as much protein when you're bulking because carbs are actually protein sparing. When you're really low carb, your body is going to use protein for energy. Whereas, when you're really high carb, you have all the carbs to use for energy. So, your body uses the protein to build muscle. Therefore, they're like they help you spare protein. So, when you're in a low low carb deficit, your body's pulling from your protein source in order to make energy, not just rebuild. You need to add more protein to make sure that you're actually rebuilding properly as well as getting the energy from it. So, I stick to a minimum of 1 g per pound of body weight. Everyone knows that number. It's so simple. Just stick to it. Make sure you're at least hitting that. And that's what you prioritize. So, then you take that. I'm 250 lb. That's 250 g of protein with four calories for every gram of protein. So, multiply that by four. you're already at 1,000 calories. And then if I'm trying to hit 4,000 calories total, then I'm going to take 20 to 30% of that total caloric intake and make that into fat. And so whatever that is in fat, I'm not that quick at math. What is that? 20% of 4,000 200 800 800 quick math. So that would be 800 calories for me in fat. So then I have 1,000 calories of protein, 800 calories of fat, and then I just fill the rest with carbs. And then there's your macros right there. That's literally how simple it is. And the most important thing is to continue to track going forward. Make sure those are hidden with right. Track your body weight. Look at yourself in the mirror. Monitor your lifts. If things are moving in the direction you're happy with, just keep doing it. That's what's important. If you start to lose weight or you're not gaining weight fast enough, you add a little bit more calories. And then you keep those ratios the exact same. You can play with that. A lot of people do better with higher carb or higher fat. And you kind of rotate through. Typically, most people do that 20 30% fat. That's what's worked best for me. I enjoy eating a lot of carbs, not crazy amounts of fat, but also as I get to the end of my bulk and I'm eating like 6,000 calories, I'll start to just cover things in olive oil just because I need anything to get those calories in. So, obviously, there's a place to start, but the number one thing in being successful at anything is knowing that you're not stuck between these confines. If it works for you, it works for you. That's all that matters. Doesn't matter if someone else tells you what to do. If I do it or not, works for you, you're making muscle. The other thing to take note when you're counting your protein, the 1 g per pound of body weight, is there are some extreme cases where when people are really like underweight, like if you weigh 100 lb and you're a male and you're tall and you're just really skinny, you might want to bump that up from the beginning. And if you're heavily overweight, so you're 400 lb and you don't have that much muscle on you, you don't need 400 g of protein. If you can eat it, I guarantee you, you will lose weight more efficiently having more protein rather than fats or carbs in your diet. but it's not necessarily for putting on muscle. So, if it's too hard to eat, 400 grams of protein, that's a lot of protein, then bump that down to something that's a little bit more appropriate. What you would guess your lean body mass would be and then use that number. It's an estimate. Again, doesn't matter. You kind of play with things as they go. If you're really overweight losing weight, all that really matters is that your calories are below what your basil basil metabolic rate is. All right. Next question is 
What Type of Food Should I Be Eating? 
what type of food to eat? Cheat meals, clean bulk, or dirty bulk. Rule of thumb for this in my absolute belief is whole foods are the most important thing. Something that grows from the earth, something that caveman could eat, anything like that, single ingredient foods are your best bet. This is because I mean it's just normal food. Much easier for your body to digest. The more food you can digest and the nutrients you can actually absorb from it, the less you actually need to eat to get the same benefit out of it. The less you have to digest, better your stomach feels, the more
you can eat. It's all just like a feedback loop to making more gains essentially. And even eating bad food causes inflammation in the gut, which slows everything down, slows your bulk down, your muscle gain down, cause inflammation in your joints, can start hurting you when you're in the gym training. There's a cascade of effects that can come from that. Not to mention that it's just not as healthy for you. So, yes, we're trying to put on muscle, but the healthiest way to do it is often also the best way to do it. So, make sure you're actually focusing on eating clean whole foods and not just going after like a nasty, dirty goal. People 
What About Cheat Meals? 
always ask about cheat meals. Why can I have cheat meal? I want a cheat meal. What's the point of cheat meals? All these things. And over the last like four or five years of my preps, I didn't get any cheat meals. And that was because of what I was talking about before. I didn't want that like gut digestion mess up. I didn't want the inflammation from it. I didn't want to ruin my sleep that night cuz I was full of all this [beep] and have my joints hurt the next day. Everything I was doing was so calculated to be the best that I was like, m I could have a cheat meal calorically and not get too fat, but it's going to have this other, you know, effects on my recovery, my digestion that's just not worth it right now. So, I didn't have those ever when I was in prep. In my off season, I like to live live a little bit. I still eat really healthy though. Like if I go to get a burger, sometimes I get a lettuce wrap, no cheese, cuz I know it's going to mess with my stomach and I make sure I stick with that. But again, it kind of depends on what your goals are. The only point of having a cheat meal is pretty much for your mental sake. If you need like a little bit of like stress relief or a break from it and if that's going to help you, then absolutely it's worth it. Even if you're a professional bodybuilder and it's going to benefit your mind and calm you down and give you a nice like cortisol brief to eat a cheat meal, then go for it. It's not the end of the world. But as me trying to be as the best in the world, I wasn't going to do that [beep] I was like, "Fuck it. I'm going to fill up on good food, food I know I can digest, just eat more of that, still sleep good, digest good, and be better for it." But that like 01% change it's going to make doesn't matter to most people. And even now as a retired bodybuilder, I'd be less tricked on doing something like that myself. So Clean Bulk vs. Dirty Bulk why would you clean bulk versus dirty bulk? I would say people with dirty bulk are just people who don't understand the indepth like minutia of how important every little thing is to your body. So I just think it's just kind of the easy way out. I need to get some calories in. I'm going to throw some shitty food down. It's also a very like a band-aid. The short-term solution for a long-term goal that you have. You just do that for a year, 2 years, even 5 years from 20 to 25. Maybe you'll get away with if you're lucky, but it will start to catch up on you. So, I just don't even recommend dirty bulking. Throw in your cheat meals if you really want them and need them. But clean bulking is the way to go. We're not just trying to get jacked. You want to take care of your body. And when you build that healthy relationship with food that you're nourishing your body, you're fueling your body. You're putting good food in your body because you care about your body. It also makes it easier to diet because then you're not craving shitty foods when you're dieting because food isn't just like a obsessive I can have now or can't have it now. It's actually something that you appreciate and you're putting good things in your body. And when I switched that mindset of eating for health rather than just like restricting now or eating as much as I can now and I was like, no, I'm putting good food to take care of my body. When I started prepping, I didn't even crave shitty food anymore. I was like, I want a little more rice and chicken, but like it is what it is. I'm dieting. And it made it much easier for me. Just a little mindset switch. As I said, it's so case dependent and bulking. Like when I was a 21year-old trying to put on as much muscle as possible. I remember putting on like 20 or 30 lbs one offseason, probably more than that. And I
was like 270 plus lbs. Midday. I was like 275ish. And I dieted down to 220. And I was like eating shitty food, messing up my digestion. Didn't care cuz I was 21 years old and I was just pushing things. And that variance made it really hard for me. So I stopped doing that. So this is kind of again back to when you should stop bulking. If you're a bodybuilder, you really only need to go like 10% over your weight. So, I started being 20 lbs over my competing weight, which made it much easier for me to come back and down and make that weight and not stress my body out too much. It made my bulking way more efficient. But I had also been doing that for a decade. So, when you're at the beginning of your career, things are different. And this is why I always say, don't just listen to what I say. Kind of just take knowledge in and try things out for yourself and see what works best for you at this point in your journey. Cuz what works for me won't necessarily work for you. When I was young, I could dirty bulk, do all the things. Same with you guys when you're young and get away with these things. When I had to eat six almost 7,000 calories sometimes, I threw in some dirty food cuz at the end of the day, I just couldn't eat another bowl of chicken rice. I was just over it. I'd have a protein shake, peanut butter and jelly, go to bed, and just it is what it is. Now that I'm 30 years old and I'm a little older, my turn is good, digestion is good, everything is clean food, and you got to be a little bit more strict. But luckily, because I had more muscle mass on me, I didn't have to eat as much food. So, I was actually eating way more food when I was younger than I am now because I've already built such a good base. So, there's always something different going on in your journey. Just grab the basics, top of the knowledge that I'm giving you right now. Start with this, track it, pay attention to how your body responds, and then adapt accordingly because it's that's the only thing that's going to make you successful, understanding your body and being able to [Music] adapt. All right, so next question. And we're in my personal supplement shop here. Best supplements for bulking. Best Supplements for Bulking Number one got to be creatine. If you're trying to put on muscle, creatine is the best muscle ever. It's good for your brain. It's good for energy. It's good for repair. It's good for putting on muscle. It's the most studied sports nutrition supplement ever. If you're not taking it, you're falling behind. There's so many of the supplements that help build muscle, but specific to bulky and trying to work hard. Number one thing I would say is digestion. I have a pretty good array of digestive supplements that you use at different times. One specifically is a glucose supplement, a GDA glucose disposal agent, typically chromium, Burberry, and a few other things in there that help. And this just helps your body actually utilize all the carbs that you're taking. I never took insulin as a bodybuilder. Some people dabble in that. And it's such a anabolic hormone because it allows your body to use more food and shuttle it into your muscle. So, there's more natural supplements to take. Like I said, Hani makes one called Evalog that has digestive enzymes and a bunch of GDAS in it. Revive has one called glucose. That's a stronger version of just the GDAS. Super helpful. You just take them with every single meal. Super easy to take. Other than that, like I said, the digestive enzymes as well as betain HCL. This bad boy right here. A lot of people don't have the proper stomach acidity for them to digest food, especially a lot of protein. When you're bulking like a bodybuilder, you're eating a lot of protein. So taking a supplement that helps like aid your gut essentially so it doesn't have to work so hard itself is super beneficial cuz the average person should not and does not need to be eating 5,000 plus calories a day. So you want to give your body as much assistance as possible to make sure like I said you're absorbing those nutrients you're actually using them and you're able to pass that food through you so you don't get bloated. You can't eat your next meal and then you just start falling behind. So digestion is absolutely key creatine and anything that helps you uptake carbs. Other than that, of course, post-workout shake, protein powder. It's like the most basic supplement in the world, but 
it's so helpful. Do you need it?
Absolutely not. Can you get away without it? You're damn good if you can, cuz I always need it both through prep or an off season. And I still really believe that a post post-workout shake is extremely important. I like to get my EAS midwork still and then right after my workout or at least soon getting in like 50 75 g of carbs with 50 g of protein. And I take that all in powder form. It's just super easy to get down. I can eat again an hour later. I know people are like, "The anabolic window doesn't matter or whatnot." Maybe it doesn't. It probably doesn't if you're getting all your food in, but if it makes me 5% better or.1% better, I'm going to do it. I'm a professional bodybuilder. I want to take everything I can. And it's not that hard to drink a protein shake after your workout. And to be able to get that protein in, starts your your anabolism immediately. Your body's not breaking down tissue anymore. You're rebuilding it. Your recovery gets in immediately. your cortisol drops because your body's starting to get into rest and digest phase which actually also helps your recovery and the quicker you get in the quicker you can eat a meal after that and then go to bed earlier to get good sleep. So all super important things to help your gains and some benefits of supplements. All right, so gym Training While on a Bulk questions. People are always asking how to train in a cut versus a bulk and all these things. And at the end of the day, it doesn't really matter that much if you're training really hard and progressively overloading on proper periodization. You're following my app and you're doing all the stuff you already know. But at the end of the day, it doesn't matter that much. But if you take a look at what's going on when you're on a bulk, if you have a little bit more fluid in your body, therefore in your joints, you have more energy. You're recovering a little bit faster, a little bit easier, there's more nutrients to uptake. And a lot of people think lift really heavy in this phase and yes you should lift really heavy but the thing you can actually get away with more so is doing more volume more intensify just a higher level of hypertrophy. So training in a bulk with a lot of food even on refeed days or whatever you want to up your volume and intensifiers on those days. So things like double, triple sets, drop sets, rest pauses, all those kind of things are what you want to do in a bulk because your body can actually handle that much stimulus and recover from it and you have enough nutrients in your body to push that much volume for a longer workout. It's kind of a different thinking than you might think when you're eating more. You want to do more weight, but you actually want to just still be heavy as possible, but more volume, more intensifiers, and it'll get more gains to use all that food. Like I Chris's Training Cycle said, there's no like optimal perfect way to do it, but that's the way I would do it. And to give an example of the way that my year used to look like with training is I would take some time off, which I would be in right now post Olympia if I were competing again. Give my body a break to kind of recover, get back into it, and then I would start rebuilding my strength for a little bit as food still low, not too high. And as my food ramped up, I would try and have my strengths already back by then. And then I would start doing a crazy amount of volume with that base of strengths. They'll get a little bit stronger at the beginning of your offseason. Then my food gets really high. Use that strength, keeping the weights the same. But then you start adding rest pauses, drop sets, super sets, all the kind of crazy [beep] of just like killing the muscle, pushing some more sets past failure, training with the training partner, all those things that would stress your nervous system a little bit more, but are easier to recover when you have more food in you. So that's the way I would get do it. And right at the end of my offseason when I'd be like peak volume, peak hypertrophy, just like hammering my body. And then when my calorie would start to drop, I would actually start increasing the weight a little bit because my volume would naturally have to come down because I don't have as much energy. glycogen stores in my muscle. Got to drop the volume a little bit, but I keep the weight as high as possible because a stronger muscle is often bigger muscle. So, if you already have the size to your muscle, maintaining strength will maintain the muscle, especially with low calories. So, sometimes it reverses what you think, but it's what I did in the last like pretty much of my whole career and it really helped me get strong,
make gains, and hold those gains throughout my prep. All right, next question. 
Should You Do Cardio While Bulking? 
Should you do cardio on a bulk? Like I said, everything is person specific, but if I had to give an overarching answer, it would be yes. for many reasons. Especially as a bodybuilder, the bigger you get, you want to take care of your heart. Obviously, cardio is a way to have the best heart health. So, keeping up with that is super important. But also, not caring about your health. If your goal is just to eat more, cardio helps you eat more. The amount of calories you're going to burn from doing 20 to 30 minutes of cardio, it's nowhere near what you can eat. You can have a bite of a sandwich and overcome the amount of calories you do in 20 minutes of cardio. So, it's really nothing to be afraid of. A lot of people like, I'm trying to huge. I don't want to do cardio cuz I don't want to sacrifice gains. That's complete [beep] Unless you're running marathons or biking two hours fasted or doing anything, you're not going to be losing any muscle. There's a few tips that you can do. Like if you are doing fast cardio because you love doing in the morning, I would 100% recommend taking an amino before that just so you're not burning through muscle. Your body at least kicks some proteins into the fish. At least get three grams of lucine, two scoops of EAS or something and you're good to go. Also, one of the easiest things to do, and this is the Stan efforting thing he used to always talk about on his diet, is doing a 105 minute walk after every single meal that you eat. You're not going to burn through the food that you ate. I promise you, you're not even going to be close to it. But what it is going to do, get your digestion going, lower your blood sugar, help your insulin a little bit, allow your body to actually utilize those nutrients that you put in your body, and then eat quicker in your next meal. Like sometimes you eat a lot and you just want to lie there and you feel like crap, like after Thanksgiving, you just want to pass out. But if you actually go for a walk, your body will start moving that food through you quicker and then you can eat again quicker. It's going to help your insulin levels, which will help your body uptake the food better. So there's a lot of benefits that come into it. So cardio good for your heart. It's actually going to help you eat more and it just helps move the food through you. So I 100% recommend cardio on a bulk. I wasn't always the best at keeping up with this if I'm being completely honest. But I did noticed to a te in the years where I didn't do cardio, but I ate as much as I could. My appetite wasn't as good and I put on fat quicker. Not muscle, but fat. When I was doing a good amount of cardio, I could eat more. I felt better. My body was utilizing it for muscle better than it was at adding fat. So, I just noticed a different body composition when my body was doing when I was choosing to do cardio in my season. So, in the end, when I was doing it all the time, I felt way better. And I absolutely recommend it to everyone. Whether you're skinny, fat, whatever. If you're skinny as [beep] do less cardio. If you're fat, do more. Don't overthink it, but focus on your [Music] heart. All right. So, another question I 
How Fast Should You Gain Weight?

if you're gaining too fast or too slow? 
And again, everything is so person dependent. It's so hard for me to even answer these, but I'm trying to give you guys something to go off of. So, take what I say and apply it to yourself in real life and adapt it. But I would say in the range of 2 to 2 lb a week is like good. It's great for gaining muscle. Again, that could be from a beginner to someone who's advanced. So, when I was young and I was like 18 years old training, I could probably put 2 lbs of muscle on if I really bulked and
trained hard and went efficient. And it life, it was incredible. It was amazing. And now over the last 4 years, I've maybe put on 4 lbs of muscle doing what I've been doing. And I've been struggling to do that. And that's me guessing cuz I'm always a little bit leaner and not as lean. So it's like my stage weight is variable. But it's really hard. So it really comes down to a lot of different things. But I think what's super important is having a high standard of which you hold yourself to. So your norm of how you look, you should be proud of how you look. You're working out to feel good, to look good, to be good. So you want to be happy with how you look. So if you start from a leaner spot and you bulk and you don't want to change too much from that, you're not going to be too fat obviously versus if you start from a fatter spot, you get a little more fat, you're more fat than that. So having that norm, that high standard to which you hold yourself to that you're proud of how you look is super important when it comes to these things. It's hard to manage tracking body fat with clips or BMIs or all these things. So, if you're taking constant check-in pictures of yourself, put your weight beside it, the amount of food you're eating with that, and you're following along those things, and you're seeing how your body's adapting, you're much better off than just like guessing what's going on. And obviously, gaining weight, there's so many variables that could be when you first start bulking. You know, your glycogen stores are filling up. You're holding on to more water. Carbs make you hold on more water. Creatine sometimes can, but then it typically levels out. So, don't stress about that. I don't want to say that. But there's so many different things that can make you hold on to weight that aren't just fat or muscle. Water, fat, or muscle are the main top three that it's going to be. So, you really need to be careful of what the difference is. If you diet, if you bulk for a year and you put on 20 lbs and then you diet down and you lose 19. For the average person, that's not a very good bulk. If you're like an elite bodybuilder, then you're doing all right. For the average person, you probably didn't need to put that 20 lbs on to gain one lb of muscle. So, try and like just even that ratio up. Again, I hate giving numbers, but if you're putting on 10% in a year, you're doing pretty good for yourself, depending on the level at which you're at. Just keep watching yourself. Don't let yourself get too fat. Be happy with how you look. Monitor your breathing, your heart rate, all these different things are super important. How you feel, how you look, end up going to the final result. So, 
How Long Should I Bulk For? 
it's all important. All right. Next 
thing is, how long should I build core? 
Minimum time to put on muscle. If you put on muscle, you put on muscle. But there is a the longer period of time you're holding it, the less likely you are to lose it when you cut really hard. That's something to take into account. If you bulk for 2 months and then you cut really hard, you're probably going to lose a good amount of that muscle versus if you're someone who's been holding on to that muscle for a year, 2 years, 3 years, or 6 months versus a 2-month bulk, you're more likely to hold on to it. text:
Whiteboard: Commitment, Structure, Community, Tracking (Transcript) 
Recorded transcript ? Formatted on 2025-11-03 (Asia/Seoul) 
What is up, YouTube? Busted out the whiteboard today. I feel like one of the last videos I was talking about lack of passion and drive. And in feeling that, I realized I need to make a change. And it was kind of coinciding with the transformation challenge I was launching. And I'm not going to make this about you have to sign up for my transformation challenge cuz it's already too late for that. You [ __ ] You're lost. You're never going to get any progress because you didn't sign up for it. Unless you did, then lucky you. But the idea of signing up for something or committing to something, creating a plan, a structure, a deadline, community, all these different things are something that help hold you accountable to actually hit your goals so much more than people understand. I think it's scary to commit to something because then you're leading yourself to failure and self-d disappointment. And if you have like limiting self-beliefs of not being able to do something, you're like feeling you're going to reinforce them. But the actual idea of committing to something, putting it out there makes you more likely like likely to succeed. And I was just thinking about that concept of how much it affected me after not having the Olympia as my thing I was committed to and then having this transformation challenge where we have these weekly calls that we're getting into. I have a YouTube channel I'm uploading all the time. I'm going to be doing a physique update at the end of this which is [ __ ] scary for me cuz I haven't looked at myself pose in a while. But all these little things that are like, okay, well if I'm doing it, I'm saying I'm doing it. I'm talking to people every week on the standard plus goals and I'm going to have 8 weeks from now another physique update. I'm holding myself accountable and that drives me to be better. And in doing so, I build the momentum and the excitement and the passion, the love to continue to do so. So anyways, the points that I wrote down, commitment equals buyin. Exactly what I was just saying, being able to say something publicly, to actually commit to something, to write it down, to agree to something, to decide on an end date. To do that, it creates buyin in your mind that you're actually doing something, and then you can commit to actually putting in the work. In an old video I did when I was talking about like changing your life, it was the idea that you create your identity and being leads to doing leads to having. So when you create an identity around someone first of all who commits to something that person who commits then commits to the actions that it takes to achieve the goal they've committed to and then you start doing the actions and then you get the thing that you want. So kind of first identity shift being commitment doing the thing starting it and then from there you're like okay [ __ ] I need a plan and a systems to start doing that you start to get specific move forward and then you're actually going to hit some goals. Second thing structure removes guesswork. So once you commit to something, creating structure in something is so important. When I was competing in Olympias, it was like, okay, I'm eating five meals a day to start. By the time I'm eight weeks out, I need to be at six meals a day. So if I can nail this now, then it's good. I So I started building structure. Every day I'm eating at the same time, the same thing moving forward. Every week I have a check-in. Every couple days, I'm calling Hanie. I'm training at the same time in the gym all the time. I created this structure around my life which allowed me not to have to think about things and I just knew it would work. So if you go dayto-day without having proper structure or
system, you're just going to end up falling off and not know where you're ending up. So having the proper specific plans of what you need to do is so important to help yourself moving forward. Next thing is comm community equals accountability. I see this so big right now in our office right now. I'm the last bodybuilder up there. Everyone's evolved into a runner and because they're all running and doing the same thing and they have a community where they're like talking about their miles, talking about the new shoes they got, the new treadmill, XY and Z, all these different things, they're all like pushing each other to get better cuz they know when they come in on Monday, they're going to be like, "How many miles do you run this weekend?" They don't want to be that [ __ ] that didn't run any miles. Tell me community is so big. When I was training for Prague and I was training with Brett and Martin in the gym and I was exhausted and these [ __ ] tanks are in there pushing every day, I'm like, I got to show these guys that classic with you guy can push harder than a bodybuilder. And that held me accountable. Can't always do that, which kind of sucks, but having friends, people online, online community, this is something really big. That's why when we built the standard challenge, every Wednesday there's a weekly call. Justin's on all of them giving sick advice. I'm on most of them. And we also have an actual community like a a forum on the circle app that's private. all these people who are on the same challenge doing the same thing are in this so they can talk to each other and hold each other accountable and that's so important because I feel like community is I could dive way deeper into that but we just [ __ ] suck at community. I was listening to a book on anxiety and it was talking about how many friends do you have that would call you to help them move out of their house if they had to move from house to house. Would they call you to move or would they call a stranger and pay them and they probably couldn't afford to do it? I want to be there for people and I want us to have like-minded goals helping us progress and get better. So, lost the community. That was kind of random, but that thought was like it all ties in. Tracking reinforces discipline. I think Justin always says, what isn't measured isn't managed. And this is so important. I think if I could give one piece of advice for people who are trying to diet, it's just track your food. Don't even think about what you're doing than tracking your food. And just having that conscious awareness of what you're putting in your body consistently allows you to progress so much better. And beyond that, tracking stuff like physique updates. I'm gonna look at my physique right now like I still look good. Again, I'm still jacked, but like compared to what I was or where I want to be, I'm not there. I'll just do it." Like, no, you're not. [ __ ] off. You know, even I can't do that [ __ ] I tell myself I'm going to do it and then I don't unless my meal plan's written down. I'm tracking my macros. Pushes you to be better. Reinforces discipline. Second last point, short-term focus equals long-term habit. So, being able to create something with a short-term goal is so important. Like, if I meet someone and they're 17 years old, 120 lbs, and they're like, "My goal is to win the Olympia." I'm like, "What else?" I'm like, "No, I'm going to be Mr. Olympia."
