So that when I was pulling away from it, I was aware of why I was feeling like things and I knew what I had to work through. But still, I'm human and that [ __ ] kind of happens. So, progress update right now. First time since like Prague, really. And I've been like training my ass off to be back in shape for this, too. So, I should have done this like right when I was injured because I put on almost 10 pounds of muscle and then I got a little bit leaner recently. So, I've been like back on diet for 4 weeks, training hard again for like a couple months and this is where we're at. Remember how to pose? Of course, I chose to do this after chest day, too. Damn, it hurts my adductors or whatever that is. I don't even know what a back job. I can't shave my back right now. It's classic post roll. There you have it. I'm honestly lightheaded right now. Damn, I haven't posed like that in a minute. But this is a pretty sick starting point for me coming off an injury. Like I said, I should have done this taking progress pics when I was like 10 lbs later post injury because I didn't. Looked like just flat even if I had lost all my muscle. I was way flatter. So, this is the starting point of me now ramping things up really seriously. My goals, I tell everyone, you have a goal to get very specific with it. And I'm struggling to get specific myself because I really want to get shredded, but I also haven't been training to build my strength back enough that I don't want to sacrifice my strength. So, I'm not leaning into a bulk phase. I'm like trying to get leaner without the sacrifice of strength is my goal. So, I'm going to keep feeding myself to which that I can perform in the gym to the level that I want where I'm progressing and load it every single week and getting stronger and stronger and stronger and I can recover from the right amount of intensity and volume that I want to, but I'm not just like jamming carbs down my face where to the point where I'm just like trying to bulk and get as strong as possible as fast as possible because I don't want to put on any more body fat than I am right now. So, the goal probably would be to be I'm 250 right now. The goal would probably be to be like three to four percent leaner than this at the exact same weight and stronger by the Olympia. That's probably what my like specific goal is for my physique to do right now. So, that's what I'm going to be working towards. Be talking about what my diet's like, doing a bunch of full days of eating. I'll be showing you guys my training. I'm going to be doing a different style of cardio now. Probably some steady state, some interval training because I just [ __ ] get bored doing steady state and I want to like really get my heart in good shape. So when I'm going to bed, my HIV is better and I'm just better conditioned. So a lot of cool stuff is coming. Yeah, that's it. I guess I feel like I could have rambled deeply about my [ __ ] ego death that I've gone through of my [ __ ] Mr. Olympia bodybuilder and being like, I'm not attached to how I look and my identity is not attached to my competing or winning or being a [ __ ] 250 lb shredded freak. And then when that started to fade, I was like, this doesn't feel good. I feel kind of like stressed. What what what's leaving me right now, you know? And I had this like conscious awareness of like that's what that was an ego death. I'm experiencing like a prolonged ego death of like letting go of the life that I used to live, the man that I used to be and kind of like expanding that where I'm not like attaching my identity to a thing and I'm just becoming who I am. I mean, I'm taking what I learned from that season of my life to become the man that I want to be, but my character of which I'm always in control of, but it's not attached to my performance or a trophy or a [ __ ] 250 lb shredded gorilla, silverback gorilla. text:
How to Build the Life You Want ? Transcript (Chris Bumstead) 
Compiled on October 28, 2025 
I hope I'm not the only one who goes through phases where I absolutely suck at like hitting goals and being consistent essentially I realized that competing in the Olympia and being a bodybuilder I was going through so many phases where I would get super ramped up and prep be super consistent on a tight schedule a tight routine everything at the same time every day doing everything I needed and then I would kind of dip down right after the I would kind of fall off I'd go to the gym when I find the time but I didn't really have a routine so I would often skip days not feel great and I was giving myself a break and when I did that a lot of other things in my life were kind of falling off and then it would slowly ramp up in my offseason you know travel and business and work is kind of crazy and then it would get super dialed and locked in again for prep and I was just realizing that I was going through these phases and I was so efficient in prep and then very inefficient other times of the year so I wanted to take some of the habits and the mindsets and the things that I applied throughout prep that made me efficient and learn how to apply them to like my day-to-day life forever consistently so I kind of dove in for the last week or so just like reflecting and writing down some things that I did and my goal is to apply them to my life going forward forever and hopefully help you guys too so I'm not going to get into too deeply because I'll be sitting here for an hour and I wrote a [ __ ] lot of [ __ ] but I'm going to just tell you guys some things I put down and maybe it'll help you first thing is a clear goal obviously at the Olympia you know there's nothing more clear than a [ __ ] goal October 14th 2024 competing at the Olympia in Las Vegas like that's the goal I got to win the Olympia but this thing that always stuck with me super cheesy and I'm not going to get into deep cuz my mom was the one who taught it to me and you can find it online but it's called smart goals it stands for specific measurable achievable relatable and time base so specific you need a very specific goal not just like I want to be strong it's like how strong do you want to be at what date do you want to be strong what lifs do you want to be explosive strong do you want to be like powerlifter strong what are your specific goals measure obviously be able to measure it attainable has to be possible relatable has to be authentic to yourself something you care about time base there has to be a time base on it like I said I'm not going to get deep into that because you guys can Google that yourself but the big thing that I wanted to touch on here that I realized I applied into becoming Mr Olympian I think really helped me drive my success in my life was instead of having a goal necessarily like a thing that would end and then like the Olympia would fall off afterwards it was more of an identity a sense of self that I was trying to build and become someone who could complete X so the way I kind of worded it and I had written this down in one of the monologues they did before a prep Series without even realizing that was the way I think it's instead of I want to win the Olympia it's the goals you could write out to be more efficient I want to be someone who X so I want to be someone who trains consistently every single day hit sets to failure never Skips a meal never cheats on his diet gets his sleep and Recovery that he needs all the these different things like that and I thought that was so important and a huge thing for me within that was it wasn't just the actions and the physical things you did but your mentality the way you think
the way you treat people and all these things cuz you might think of the identity of the champion as someone who is a little bit you know edges on the side of arrogance super cocky confident and that's what winners do because a lot of people we see in the media are like that but that wasn't relatable or authentic to me so the self I wanted to betray before I was the champion was the humble respect full champion who treated everybody the same whether it was a former Mr Olympia backstage a stage Marshal a security guard whoever it might be the person the champion I wanted to be with someone who embodied that respect because I knew people would be looking up to me when I became this Champion not only for what I did but who I was and I wanted to be someone that my mom and their moms would be proud of if that's how they were acting so the next thing I kind of dove into here was you have an identity and then creating a list of things and defining very specifically what those people do and this comes back to that goal is I want to be someone who X so I want to be someone who you know what does Mr Olympia do and I you write that list down and you know you treat people with respect you're humble you go to the gym every single day whether it's to train or to do active recovering to stretch to hit ABS to hit your accessory body parts you know you never cheat on your diet and doing these things as much as possible the more you define these habits and you live these habits you will naturally become the success that you want to achieve so instead of chasing after that goal you become the identity and the person that will naturally attract that goal I think the biggest thing that people always come to me and ask me when I'm doing like meet and greets and they ask me it's always like how do I start what do I do how do I start I have all these things XY andz and you can watch a million YouTube videos read a million books and sometimes you get like overwhelmed by the amount of steps that are out there and and I mean nothing matters unless you actually do it so taking action is the most important hardest part you know I've always had this mindset that you are not what you think you're not who you think you are you just simply are what you repeatedly do so you can think positive things you can think this is huge in relationships you know like I could tell my my wife I think you're beautiful I think I love you I just don't say it well she's not going to know and feel it unless I show her with my actions and it's the same at anything in life so taking action is the most crucial point of everything and I think what people [ __ ] up is they get over overwhelmed with too many steps and things to do so this is going to be the most basic tip but the most important one if you take anything away from this build an identity and start [ __ ] small to build momentum those three things are everything when you break that down so for example when I used to be in college I used to drink three times a week get like blackout drunk go out with my friends and I loved it you know I love the social life I was in college hanging out with people was the only time my life had to be able to live like that and I was aware of that so I didn't want to sacrifice that so I did that for a period of time but then I wanted to take bodybuilding more seriously I was on the edge of going pro and I knew I had a lot of potential in me but I knew my lifestyle was holding me back but I also wasn't ready to sacrifice my social life yet so instead of just telling myself all right I'm going to stop drinking stop going out go to bed at 9:00 p.m. wake up at 6:00 a.m. do my cardio never miss a meal do all these things I was like I'm eating pretty good still cheating a lot cuz I like going out my friends and I love going out at night but I'm going to stop drinking so I still stayed out until 2 a.m. every night but I made one small change and that would to stop drinking and just that alone waking up not hung over and not wanting to eat bacon and [ __ ] God knows what else for breakfast CU you're hung over and tired and lazy having a bad workout horrible recovery from the alcohol throwing up your system I was able to make a decent amount of progress from that alone and the momentum I built from that one small change encouraged me to want to make more changes and eventually I stopped going out completely started
to go to bed early I started to clean up my diet and I started to make all these little changes that eventually that literal year was the year that I turned Pro won two pro shows and made it to the Olympia just from making these subtle changes and it was huge and the one change I made made this Cascade effect into everything in my life and I think starting small in order to build momentum and being conscious that you were starting small intentionally to build momentum is huge so the goal when you're starting something especially if you're fresh the goal is to be consistent not perfect so create an identity Define what that person does start small and make your goal to pick something that you can be consistent with where imp perfect I don't need you achieve the whole list pick one start with that and with that momentum start another one and another one and another one and after a while once you're embodying these habits these actions and these behaviors without even thinking of your goal anymore you're going to achieve your goal as long as you're doing this like well thought out and the idea with momentum is I mean as anything if you're driving a car and you take your foot off the brake and you roll into a wall you're going to just [ __ ] tap into the wall [ __ ] up your car a little bit if you're driving 150 miles per hour at a brick wall and just [ __ ] fly right through that thing probably keep going there through at the other side you might you know get a little scratches on your car but you're still moving it doesn't stop you because you have so much momentum and that's the same thing with this after starting making those small changes when I was young and building these habits over time I didn't even feel like it was like I was dieting I didn't feel like I was eating healthy I didn't feel like I was training hard it was just life it who I was and it was what I did so when something came in the way whether I was in prep and it was my lat tear my hamstring tear 2018 when I was in the hospital you know last year I had a minor hamstring tear I didn't even really talk about it became the thing where I didn't even have a chance to hold me back because I had so much momentum had such an identity attached to behaviors that I did that when something came in to stop me I just kept rolling forward through it after so a lat tear would be something that would hold me back for a little bit and I'd be immediately back on my [ __ ] moving forward getting better and better and I can't stress that enough that momentum is like the secret to get through stuff cuz when things are so habitual that you don't have to think about them that when chaos hits in your life whether it be personal stressful mental emotional physical your habits you don't have to think about they take less energy so you just keep moving forward you keep getting better better and it's [ __ ] everything all right so the next little tip amongst all these all are kind of the actionable steps but the other thing that I realized I did without knowing it is selft talk and like personal accountability I tie these in together because how you talk to yourself is sometimes how you hold yourself accountable but personal accountability means you're responsible for your own life which means you are Empower you have the power to control and change your life so personal accountability equals power power is the ability to do whatever the [ __ ] you want in your life so no one else wants you to [ __ ] hit your goals like you do no one cares what you do Beyond yourself so make sure you're holding yourself accountable you're not waiting for someone else to encourage you you're waiting for someone else to go to the gym do this or that you really have to hold yourself accountable you know it's in the selft talk piece a little thing that I this is how I label it now but I wasn't intentionally doing it in purpose in the time but I was always talk to myself in my head like I was a mentor talking to my Apprentice you know there's always like your thoughts in your mind and then there's the thinker of the thoughts you know there's two kind of when you're talking to yourself in your head there's someone talking and then there's someone paying attention so there's kind of two like dualistic identities inside your brain at any given time and I viewed it as like a mentor who is the retired six-time Mr Olympia talking to the amateur The Apprentice who
wanted to become that and was embodying that and working towards that so when I would talk to myself like come on champ come on you want to be Mr Olympia like let's get after it it was like my future Mr Olympia self talking to myself and when I would be on a treadmill I'd be supposed to do 30 minutes 25 minutes goes by I'm like add bored tired want to go eat breakfast deep in prep whatever and I get off I'd get off and talk to myself like come on champ like is that what Mr Olympia does is Mr Olympia to get out five minutes before his cardio's done I'm like [ __ ] and I drag myself back on finish my cardio and actually do it right same thing with you know a set if I'm aiming for 10 I get eight and I just put the weights down and I'm like what the [ __ ] like you could have gotten 10 maybe I Take 5 minutes do another set that I'm not even supposed to do to hit that 10 just to hold myself accountable or I get right back on and do two more three more reps just to make sure I'm hitting that 10 that I was supposed to but holding yourself accountable and having the proper self talk is important and I don't think this comes from shame I don't think shaming yourself calling yourself a piece of [ __ ] like you fat [ __ ] get after it all these things I don't personally believe that works at all I think if you call yourself a fat [ __ ] and you begin to identify as a fat [ __ ] you will continue to act like a fat [ __ ] so not to use fat shaming as an example at all but that's a huge one that people do you know that eat bad [ __ ] I'm so fat I'm so fat I'm going to keep eating bad like no it's don't shame yourself positive reinforcement talk to yourself from like a oneup position in a positive form hold yourself accountable to be better not to shame yourself for being worse I think that's absolutely huge positivity is [ __ ] massive and I think so many people think driving forward from shame works because it does for a period of time but if you're trying to be a six-time Mr Olympia or do something consistently I truly believe that everything I just listed of building identity a habits a self-accountability the positive selft talk those are the only ways to properly sustain things obviously within that you know the goal of everything I'm talking about I'm trying to focus more on like mental things and the mental side of things and even in the behavior something I didn't mention if I was like Mr Olympia is someone who always has their head on right what does someone who has their head on right do you know they self-reflect they Journal they go to therapy they talk about their emotions and their feelings they let things out they don't hold it all in and these were all part of the identity that I began to build to be create a mind set that could do anything rather than just trying to accomplish one thing and I think that was the most important thing that I kind of naturally built over time and I didn't even realize what I was doing I was just again starting small and building habits creating identity around something I wanted to be knowing I wanted to be Mr Olympia and embodying that next thing I knew I was [ __ ] looking back retiring and I had done it six times and I was like wow like you did it and it was pretty cool so you know there's a lot of these things that I'm going to try to apply to absolutely everything in my life such as you know being a good father defining what that means to me being someone who you know is present when his kids around is emotionally there for his daughter is you know drives them to their games leaves work early because priority is family these little things that are important to me something that I want to Define so I know who I want to be and I'm aware of it and then I can actually act and live it out so yeah that's pretty much it but essentially clear outcome clear goal Google smart goals I don't need to do that consistent identity Define what that identity is start small build momentum and just [ __ ] create an identity be someone who X and Define that very specifically not I want to be jacked I want to be someone who and what are the attributes that you would view as someone who is jacked use that as an example obviously because it's easy for me to use selft talk being positive personal accountability it all comes down to yourself you know I don't even repeat myself it is what it is but yeah this is something that I've been personally reflecting on and I just wanted to share that with you guys I think you know there's a
lot of lessons that I learned that I didn't even understand I was learning and you know there's two times to learn from something it's from the experience and then from reflecting on the experience and I think from reflecting on the experience is when you truly are able to learn and make changes to your life going forward because the greatest achievement of accomplishing your goals isn't the goal it's who you become and accomplishing those goals so I want to do my best to be able to share a lot of the things I did hopefully help you guys move forward and as I doing my self-reflection on the experience I just lived I'm going to try and kind of share these little tidbits if you will with you guys so sorry for the rant hope that made sense I tried to I literally have like five bullet points on my phone that I'm going off from a 10 minute video however long I'm talking so hopefully it made sense but appreciate you guys thanks for watching

Date: 2025-11-03 
All right. What is up, YouTube? We are finally back in America. I was on a two week hiatus going around Europe. Had my official wedding. Technically, I've already been married for like two years, but we had a official wedding rather than just a courthouse celebration that we had before. We're down to Italy. Small wedding. Had like eight people there. Then we did a little trip to Austria after with Bradley. And then we went to Paris after that. It was a great trip, but I don't recommend traveling with a toddler, especially like 15 months when she's just becoming a toddler and she did not want to sleep. She got sick. We all got sick. It was chaos, but it was honestly really nice to have like intentional time together. I can finally wear a ring now. I've been married, but I haven't worn a ring because we wanted to have the official wedding to do this. Not to get super cheesy with you guys, but it's had me reflecting a lot about like love and marriage and all that kind of stuff. And I feel like there's a lot of skepticism amongst people that I talk to around it. or like at least a lot of people which makes sense given like divorce rates are like just under 50% now which means if you're in a relationship of two people I hope or maybe you're by yourself or three I don't know then odds are even higher 50% chance of divorce rate there's a pretty much a high rate that one of you guys parents had a divorce so your idea of a relationship ends in divorce and people don't trust institutions no one trusts the government people don't trust religion people don't even trust family structures anymore so it's become this like negative thing around it but we live in a society that really like pushes is like individuality and like self-made selfish pursuits like gain, make money, do stuff. Especially like men even are like don't be vulnerable, don't lean on people, like be the strong person who provides but don't need anything, just don't need anything ever. it's like this whole mistrust of things. And I feel like that's trickled into like marriage. And even if it's something that's broken in our society, I don't think there's something that's wrong with it in that sense. I think maybe our society might be hurting because stuff like that is broken. long- winded way to say having the wedding, writing our vows, having the moments of just like so much focus on love. I feel like it made me really reflect that like the most beautiful thing I've really built in my life is my marriage and my relationship with Courtney. And everything is going to fade. The body that I build and work for every day, the money you make, the business you have, it all fades. But if you do it right, your relationship is the one thing where at the end of life, it is at its strongest, best point ever. And I think there's something so beautiful, especially like me, like I talk about society, the push to be individualistic or whatever. That was me. I was like convincing Courtney when we were young that you don't need anyone. You don't need anything. Relationships are nice, but you don't need your partner and all this stuff. And learning over time, especially with her help of like how important and helpful it is to have someone that you trust in every capacity to like lean on when time gets hard and to share everything that you have going on with. It's everything in life. But when I really think of like everything I have going on in my life, if I lost all of it, but I had Courtney and Bradley, I'd be great. And there's so much like peace in my heart and safety and security that I have in that. And I just think it's something that so many people are missing. And
it's it's hard. It's probably the hardest thing that you can build in the relationship. But instead of it being something that like traps you, it actually creates more like peace and freedom in your life. It creates more like security. You know, someone who can actually hold you accountable. They're not holding you back from growth. They're actually creating a mirror for you to see your faults in yourself of places where you can get better. And if you have a partner like Courtney who holds me accountable when I'm not being my best self, trust me, I have points I can be an [ __ ] It definitely happens where I blurt out things I don't mean and she holds me accountable and I'm able to look and reflect and repair the relationship through it and find why it's coming out of me and why it's getting put onto her. I think there's nothing in my life more that's made me grow than my relationship with her to make me become a better person, a better father, a better everything. And I think just having someone where you know I think why the marriage is so important to me is because you're committing that no matter what you're not giving up on each other. Like in a life where everything is so temporary right now like stuff is so fleeting. Marriage is like the one thing where no matter what like we're going to figure it out. We might go through hell, go through hard times, go through fights, but always if our goal is at the end we will always be together then we need to repair along the way and continue to work towards that common goal of being together. other. And I just think there's something so beautiful about that of just like an absolute like I wear this vow on my hand that like I will always put you first. I will always take care of our relationship. text:
Grocery Haul & Gym Vlog ? Clean Transcript 
Sam?s Club haul, snack picks, donations, and a light pull day?(Edited for readability; filler removed, key moments Prepared: Oct 27, 2025 
Intro at Sam?s Club 
[Music] 
?What is up, YouTube!? Back at Sam?s Club for a quick grocery haul. Easing back into training post?hair procedure; not full sessions yet, but dialing diet back in. Last big shop before the holidays; snacks allowed (not on prep). 
Proteins & Mains (why each) 
? Oven?roasted turkey breast ? sandwich staple; stuffs it heavy with meat. 
? Atlantic salmon ? ?fresh fats + omega?3s,? eating 1?2x/day lately; tastes great post?prep. ? Ground bison ? prefers flavor over beef; leans cleaner vs. typical farmed beef. 
? Chicken breast ? boneless, skinless; Courtney nails the pan?fry (aminos help the flavor). ? Beef tenderloin (filet) ? go?to steak cut: lean, tender; cooks beautifully even if ?less 
 beefy.? 
Veg & Carbs (go?to prep) 
? Chopped kale kit (uses greens only) ? toss with olive/coconut oil; oven or pan until 
 crispy; add to chicken & rice bowls. 
? Clementines ? nostalgic; packs 4?5/day. ?Vitamin C, Florida life.? 
? Sweet potatoes ? peeled, chopped, heavy coconut oil, 350?F roast until crisp (coconut oil  crisps best); burn a little for fry vibe. 
? Frozen veggie medley ? ?lazy stir?fry hack?: microwave 1?2 min, then pan?crisp, add rice &  chicken. 
Snacks & Treats (off?prep picks) 
? Chicken strips (?nuggets but bougier?) ? lighter, crisp breading; dip ideas: honey?mustard  + mayo OR ketchup + sriracha. 
? Peanut?butter pretzel bites ? airport weakness; far cheaper by the tub; decent calories  for a snack. 
? Almond butter (ingredients check) ? prefers just almonds + salt; drizzles on morning 
 toast. 
? Passing on: pizza bagels, cereal (?Raisin Bran?), Nutella?for now. ?Bulk coming in the New  Year.? 
Supplements on Shelf 
Raw Nutrition at Sam?s Club ? pre, creatine sold through fast; protein still stocked. Cool moment to see it in big?box retail (and selling out). 
Holiday Giveback Run (same trip) 
Grabs toys/electronics for donations + a simple giveaway (iPad, AirPods, Apple Watch, massage gun, etc.). 
Entry was: like the post + follow RAW (Christmas spirit, thank you to supporters).
Home/Checkout Bits 
?Empty sack ? full sack.? Banter about bikes, hats, and a Gen?2 Raptor in the lot. Jokes about ?dad flavors? (olives, black licorice, root beer starting to hit). 
Light Pull Day (easing back in) 
Plan: 3?4 sessions/week; push/pull/legs split to re?introduce movement. Notes: 
? Mobility/G.B.R.S. work left hips/obliques lit up?time off made tightness worse. Movement >  no movement. 
? More free weights for stability: barbell rows, one?arm DB rows, pull?ups. Pull?downs don?t  translate 1:1 to pull?ups; wants proficiency at pull?ups. 
? Stability cue on 1?arm DB row: don?t let the hip do the pulling. Protract/retract scap,  keep hip quiet so the back does the work. 
? Pull?ups: first set ?10; short rests drop reps fast. Focus on clean chin?over and  controlled reps. 
? Feeling ?skinny?fat? vanished with a pump?muscle was just ?sleepy.? Goal: maintain,  rebuild smartly. 
Family & Life 
? Baby update: girl dad incoming; excited + a little scared for teen years. ? Menthol/CBD pain balm helped travel headache/neck tension (?new cologne??). ? CrossFit talk: fun thought experiment; respects the sport, no plans to disrespect athletes  by showing up unprepared. Maybe a local WOD someday; games would take years. ? ?Not sacrificing biceps for kipping.? (Fragile biceps history?lat/biceps tears;  bodybuilding arms stay.) 
Wrap?Up 
That?s a wrap on 2023. Heading to Chicago/Canada. Might do a year?recap video (therapy!)?wild year. 
?Merry Christmas, happy holidays?see you in the New Year.? ? Chris & Courtney Quick Grocery List (at a glance) 
Proteins: turkey breast, salmon, ground bison, chicken breast, beef tenderloin (filet). Carbs/veg: sweet potatoes, kale (for crisped greens), frozen veggie medley, clementines. Snacks/condiments: chicken strips, peanut?butter pretzels, almond butter; dips (honey?mustard + mayo, ketchup + sriracha). 
Staples skipped (this time): pizza bagels, cereal, Nutella, egg whites (doing whole eggs instead).

name: 2025-10-28-(Cutting).pdf
text:
Cutting ? Video Transcript 
Source: User-provided transcript 
Prepared on 2025-10-26 
Notes 
This is a cleaned, formatted transcript based on your text. Short, title-like lines were treated as section headers (e.g., ?How Do I Start a Cut??).
Intro 
[Music] What is up, YouTube? I was going to do a full day of eating today, which will come soon, but I remembered when I did that ultimate guide to bulking, a lot of people requested the ultimate guide to cutting. So, I'm going to be doing that instead. Still making a meal right now, eating clean, but I'm going to be running you guys through just some tips and tricks that I learned on the long along the way of my bodybuilding career on how to get shredded. It's also because I'm kind of going into like a mini cut of myself, at least trying to lean up while maintain muscle, not a hard tread. But I'll be talking about what I do, but mainly about a lot of questions that I get about it. Similar 
How Do I Know When to Cut? 
to the bulking one, it started off with how do I know when to cut and how long do I cut for? And again, it's very dependent on what your goals are. But in my opinion, when you start to lose your abs, for me especially, cuz my abs are something that are gone pretty late. So when I have a lot of body fat, I'll lose them. But if you have no ab showing anymore, you might be at the point of a bulk where you're starting to lose and plateau and you need to cut down, you know, fix your insulin sensitivity, your metabolism, your digestion, a lot of things that are better off in a cut. So being able to do things like eat food in a conscious state, if you're in a high stress state, eating food, not really chewing, swallowing, like big pieces, that's going to create bad digestion, mess up your gut, not be able to absorb nutrients properly. Again, like I keep talking about, spike your cortisol, hold on fat more, just ruin a lot of things. So having digestive supplements if you need to take a betain HCL before you eat, some gut health products, something that's going to help you digest, digest enzymes, whatever it may be. But even just being off your phone, chewing your food more, being intentional with it, doing those 10 minutes walks after every single meal can help you so much in progressing and moving forward. And just these little tips and things that you can add throughout the day. And the more touch points that you have in the day that are progressing you towards your goal, the more conscious you are of your goal and the more likely you're going to continue to make good decisions. to doing that on top of creating a plan while you're at the beginning of the day or have the beginning of the weekend full of energy and follow that plan when you're tired throughout. You're setting yourself up for success and you're in a much better position than most people. So, at the end of the day, cutting sucks. It can be hard. It can be also be easy when you get to a certain point, but if you want to get shredded, it's not always fun. But if you want to get something, got to go through hard [beep] sometimes. It's just the way it is. If you want to drive results that most people don't get, you have to do things that most people won't do, and it's the way it is. So, all these tips and tricks are something that help and there's so much more I could talk about and even myself now being on a diet and progressing forward in all the YouTube videos to come, I'll keep implementing little tips and tricks and showing you how I'm doing it and adapting what I'm trying, what's worked for me, what doesn't. So, I'll continue to talk about this cuz there's so much more that you can do. But at the end of the day, like I said, create a plan, stick to it, check your food, eat healthy food, and take care of your body because being healthy is what matters. So, have a good reason to do what you're doing, and it will work out better in the end. Yeah, that's my ramble on cutting for the day. So, I hope you guys enjoyed this. If you guys want to see me ramble on other random topics, plan in life, let me know. Like I said, I will continuously be talking about this stuff going forward. So, thank you guys for watching.
